title.narrative: Improve access to and capacity of health services to provide emergency primary care to Venezuelans

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to reduce preventable morbidity and mortality by strengthening access to and capacity of health services to provide emergency and essential primary care. This WHO project supports 10 health facilities, provides quick turnover emergency health supplies, personal protective equipment (PPE) and trains local health teams among other activities. The project provides life-saving assistance to 60,340 people, including 29,000 women, 20,500 men, 11,000 children, and 1,500 persons with disabilities.

owner-org.narrative: UN OCHA Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF)

organisation.narrative: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)

mailing-address.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF), 2 United Nations Plaza (DC2), East 44th street (13th floor), United Nations, New York, USA

description.narrative: Disbursement to CERF Project Improve access to and capacity of health services to provide emergency primary care to Venezuelans

condition.narrative: CERF funding is based on an agreed proposal, including specific planned outcomes and outputs.

description.narrative: Children, girls, adolescents, men and women in situation of vulnerability have improved access to essential health services in hospitals and primary healthcare facilities in prioritized communities in the municipalities of Tucupita, Casacoima (Delta Amacuro), Bermúdez and Valdez (Sucre)
H.7 Number of functional health facilities supported (detect and care for women's health, maternal and perinatal health, SRH, CCD, including health promotion and disease prevention actions)
Population proportion of the prioritized communities that receive some type of health care service by supported facilities (% of the total direct beneficiaries - 48,272 persons)
